thread.title: Middle schoolers shake sticks, prepare for postseason
thread.title_full: Middle schoolers shake sticks, prepare for postseason

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Middle schoolers shake sticks, prepare for postseason
text:
Middle schoolers shake sticks, prepare for postseason Defending champ Troy Howard first, Oceanside fourth, Camden-Rockport fifth By Staff | Oct 08, 2015 Photo by: Mark Haskell Camden-Rockport's Meredith Luce, left, and Alyssa Bland, right, as well as Oceanside's Jade Philip during a Busline League middle school field hockey game. The Schooners and Mariners played to a scoreless tie on Oct. 2. View More... 
The Busline League middle school field hockey regular season has swung to a close with the postseason set to begin. 
There are five teams in the league: Oceanside of Thomaston/Rockland/St. George, Camden-Rockport Middle School of Camden, Troy Howard Middle School of Belfast, Boothbay Region Elementary School and Great Salt Bay of Damariscotta. 
Troy Howard is the three-time defending league champions and has won most of the titles in recent decades. 
The postseason will begin on Wednesday, Oct. 14, with the league championship game slated for Monday, Oct. 19 at Boothbay. 
The final standings were: 1, Troy Howard; 2, Boothbay; 3, Great Salt Bay; 4, Oceanside; and 5, Camden-Rockport. 
Thus, the No. 5 Schooners will travel to face the No. 4 Mariners on Wednesday, Oct. 14 at 3:45 p.m. in a play-in game. The winner will advance to face top-seeded Troy Howard in a semifinal game, while No. 3 Great Salt Bay will travel to face No. 2 Boothbay in another semifinal game. 
Both semifinal games are scheduled for Thursday, Oct. 15. 
The following is a recap of the lone reported result from the season: 
Field hockey 
Oceanside 0, Camden Hills 0 
At Camden Oct. 2, the Mariners and Schooners battled to a scoreless tie. 
Mariner coach Andrea Garver said she was pleased with her team's play. 
“Our defense was exceptional and Sophia Campbell did a great job moving the ball from side to side and forward up the field,” she said. “Audrey Young and Chloe Simmons did a great job inside the defensive circle, keeping the ball away from our goalie and Alexa Barstow made a couple of key saves in the goal. Our younger players did a great job subbing in and keeping up the pace with Emma Gerrish and Seanna Montgomery playing well in the midfield.” 
“The teams both battled very well and were locked in an even contest for the entire game,” said Schooner coach Matthew Smith. “Though CRMS had the majority of possession, Oceanside had some good counter attacks and nearly took the win at the end of regular time.”
